data.question: What type of luminescence do many gold(I) complexes exhibit at room temperature?
What is the coordination number of gold(I) in the first polymeric gold(I) complexes described in the article?
What type of ligands are used in the first polymeric gold(I) complexes?
What is the structure of complex 3 described as?
What is the structure of complex 4 described as?
What is the empirical formula of the isomers shown in Chart 1?
Why might 3-coordinate gold(I) complexes be of interest for synthesis?
data.answer: Because many 3-coordinate gold(I) complexes are strongly luminescent

data.question: Why do complexes 3 and 4 exhibit strong room-temperature luminescence?
data.answer: Due to their [AuP3]+ centers and the lack of significant extended conjugation

data.question: What hypothesis was tested to achieve polymeric structures?
data.answer: That diphosphines which cannot chelate or which have a preference for the anti conformation might give polymeric structures

data.question: What does the similarity in the emissions of complexes 3 and 4 suggest?
data.answer: Very little extended conjugation present in these complexes

data.question: What principle is applicable to the synthesis by self-assembly of other coordination polymers?
data.answer: The principle based on the conformational preferences of the diphosphine ligands

data.question: What does the observation of strong luminescence in complexes 3 and 4 indicate?
Are 2-coordinate gold(I) centers in rigid-rod polymers strongly luminescent?
Is the emission from complexes 3 and 4 attributed to a primarily metal-centred transition?
Are polymeric complexes with 3-coordinate gold(I) centers previously known before this article?
Is conjugation through the gold centers indicated by a red-shift in luminescence?
Do complexes 3 and 4 have the same type of luminescence?
Is the structure of complex 4 predictable from the double ring-opening polymerization of complex 2?
Does the presence of saturated diphosphine in complex 4 allow for extended conjugation?
